resources.string: Welcome to the SaFoDel learning mode
Preparing you for safer food deliveries on bicycle in Victoria
\'Don\'t put your life at risk for other\'s convenience\'
Find out how to ride safely while delivering food
Find information on using E-Bikes for food delivery
Find out the cycling gear you need to deliver safe
Find out the measure for handling the bike accident
Here are a few safety tips for delivering food on bicycle
Worried about your safety while delivering at night? Follow these tips to stay safe
Here are a few significant road signs you must understand
E-bikes are rising in popularity especially in the food delivery community, here\'s why
Wondering whether the e-bike rules and regulations are different?
Be aware of the risks of delivering on an e-bike
Wearing proper safety gear while delivering food is a must. Find more about the essential safety gear below
Worried about forgetting essential safety gear?\nFollow this checklist for a quick heads up!
Bicycle helmets should have a sticker showing the Australian Standard <font color="#EE0000">AS 2063, AS/NZS 2063</font>!
Steps to follow in the event of an accident
Information about current movements in gig workers\' rights
Find out information regarding insurance claims

Welcome to learning mode
It's time to know more about the application
Click Next for the next step
Click Close for leaving this mode
Food delivery riders are not given enough safety training and local traffic knowledge, making them unacceptably vulnerable
What is SaFoDel?\nWe help you prepare for a safe food delivery experience on a bike. Currently, these services focused on the Victorian riders
Home button allows you to return home page directly
Map button allows you to see the historical accident locations in Victoria with details
ACCIDENT-TRENDS button allows to check the trends in historical accident in different suburbs
QUIZ-YOURSELF button allows you to test your understanding of road rules while delivering food
Ride-Safer button allows you to find out how to ride safely while delivering food
Delivery-on-E-Bike button allows you to find information on using e-bike for food delivery
Safety-Gear button allows you to find out the cycling gear you need to deliver safe
In-an-Accident button allows you to find out the measure for handling the bike accident

Left Menu has
ABOUT APP:
Understand the purpose of this app

ABOUT US:
Know more about the developer team
Bicycle crashes are marginally more common (55%) at intersections
TIP: If you want to turn right at any intersection, doing a hook turn is often a safer option (unless a sign prohibits it)
15% of bike rider casualties occur when a driver or rider who is turning right fails to give way to an oncoming vehicle travelling straight through
TIP: If you are at intersections without traffic lights, signs or road lines, give way to any vehicle entering or approaching the intersection from your right
8% of bike rider casualties occur when a driver opens their door into the path of a bike rider
TIP: While it is never the rider\'s fault when hit by an opening door, you must be aware of the risk and position themselves so that any chance of a collision is reduced
Delivery Partners recommend you not to listen to music while delivering
Don’t be distracted by the use of phone or listening to music while delivering. Instead use hands-free GPS
Take extra care when cycling at night. It is harder for drivers to see you and for you to see hazards
Try to ride on well-lit roads and wear bright or light coloured clothing or a reflective vest
Always use front and rear lights
Keep backup lights or a portable charger
Avoid delivering in areas with poor lighting
Make riding twice as easy as push bikes
Comes in handy when riding up hills or over long distances
No need to break the bank as they’re generally cheaper to rent
The Victorian Government allows a maximum power of 250 watts
A maximum speed of 25 km/h is allowed if the rider is pedalling
All other rules are the same as pedal bicycles
Buying a high-speed e-bike may lead to faster deliveries but it is illegal
TIP: Be sure to check the government guidelines before buying an e-bike
Too much initial throttle can cause injury
TIP: Get accustomed to riding an e-bike before actually going out for your first delivery
The higher price for e-bikes has seen more thefts of e-bikes over regular bikes
TIP: Make sure you lock your bike properly
A checklist of necessary safety equipment
The following labels indicate a helmet has been approved
Bicycle helmets reduce the chances of a serious head injury by almost 70%
Warm gloves not only protect you from cold but also help you maintain safe grip at all times
With the lockdown restrictions on, food delivery companies require masks or face covers for all drivers
Always be prepared for bad weather and carry a rain jacket in your delivery bag
In the unfortunate event of a bike accident these are some steps to look after yourself
Make sure you\'re okay, contact help if needed and try place yourself in a safe location if your accident was on the road
Collect details of those involved in accident and any witnesses as they may be necessary for insurance purposes later on
Always give priority to your health and safety. Even if you feel it is only a small incident, it\'s best to see a doctor
Report the incident to the police as well as let your platform know you\'ve been in an accident as they may offer assistance
Typically gig economy workers are treated as independent contractors and therefore lack some ordinary working protections and benefits
It is important to know that food delivery platforms have different working contracts and manage the working relationship differently
Uber Eats treats it’s riders as independent contractors while a recent ruling Deliveroo drivers as employees
How gig workers are treated is a growing area, groups like the transport workers union (TWU) are fighting for gig workers to have more rights
Most delivery companies offer a support package for driver and delivery partners, helping to cover partners should something go wrong while using their platform
To find out the insurance details provided by your food delivery platform, select your partner below
The TAC (Transport Accident Commission) provides No Fault Benefits under certain terms and conditions
Roads that get especially slippery with wet weather, reduce your speed and be careful
Roadwork or construction ahead, be prepared to be slow down, stop, encounter detours or traffic control
Keep an eye out for signs that prohibit bike parking, not following these signs could have you fined or your bike seized
Paths that are for both cyclists and pedestrians, it\'s expected pedestrians stay to the left and cyclists warn when they\'re approaching
An intersection where you can only turn right with a hook turn though it is recommended cyclists do hook turns rather than directly turn right at as it is often safer
Places where cyclists must dismount and walk instead of ride (usually at pedestrian crossings or bridges)
What is the maximum speed you can ride your e-bike?
The Australian government has set a strict speed limit of 25 Km/h on e-bikes
Even if a road has a bike lane, can you ignore riding on it?
Ride in bike lanes where they are provided, unless impractical to do so
As a delivery rider, should you stop when you see tram passengers getting off?
Bike riders must stop behind a tram that has stopped at a tram stop, to allow passengers to get on and off safely
Should you signal when turning right?
Bike riders must signal when turning right, and can help share the road more safely by riding predictably, using eye contact and indicating all changes of direction
Are you allowed to ride on a footpath while delivering food?
Any bike rider must use a front light, rear light (flashing or steady), and a rear red reflector when riding at night or in conditions where visibility is poor.
Whenever you are changing lanes, is it not your responsibility to give way and look for vehicles already in that lane?
Whenever you change lanes from one marked lane or line of traffic to another, you must give way to vehicles already in that lane or line of traffic..
You can wear any helmet while delivering, regardless of its ratings.
Cyclists need to wear a securely fitted and fastened helmet with a mark of compliance with the Australian Standard
Test your understanding for road rules
Please make sure you prepare everything on the checklist
Awesome! It\'s time to start your food delivering journey!
